Richard Teague

Astronomer at the University of Michigan

Email: rteague@umich.edu

About Me

Iâ€™m an postdoctoral fellow at the University of Michigan working in the group of Prof. Ted Bergin on understanding planet formation. I have previously studied at the Unversity of Edinburgh for my MPhys in Astrophysics, then at MPIA in Heidelberg where I obtained my PhD in Astronomy, supervised by Prof. Thomas Henning and Dr. Dmitry Semenov.

I work primarily with radio observations of simple molecules in protoplanetary disks, the sites of planet formation. I am mostly interested in the dynamics of the gas as this provides a unique way of searching for embedded planets. I also work extensively on inferring the physical and chemical structures of these disks in order to better interpret the dynamical information we extract. My ADS Library contains a list of all my publications.

Diversity, Equity and Inclusion

A diverse and inclusive astronomy is important for everyone. I am working as part of the UMich Astronomy Diversity, Equity and Inclusion committe to help implement iniatives aimed at creating a more inclusive department. As part of this, I run the monthly DEI journal club, Equitea where we discuss recent papers, talks or issues relating to DEI.

Projects

eddy

github.com/richteague/eddy

A suite of tools written in Python to extract kinematical information from spectrally resolved line emission in protoplanetary disks. eddy has been used to infer the presence of unseen planets and make the first confirmation of grain trapping in pressure maxima.

bettermoments

github.com/richteague/bettermoments

Tired of having to play around with masks and clipping thresholds to get a nice looking rotation or emission map? betteremoments is here to help!

This is a simple package written with Dan Foreman-Mackey to quickly make moment maps from position-position-velocity cubes without the need for clipping. And, as a bonus, returns uncertainties! A short artcile about this method used can be found at the Research Notes of the AAS.
